newsitem.title: UK: Zeneca drops fungal disease drug.
newsitem.headline: Zeneca drops fungal disease drug.

text.p: British drug group Zeneca Group Plc said on Tuesday it had dropped the development of a drug for serious fungal diseases because of problems with the way the drug works.

Chief executive David Barnes told a news conference that Zeneca's partner on the drug, Japan's Mochida Pharmaceutical Co Ltd, would continue its own development programme using lower doses and different indications for the product.
Barnes said Zeneca, which announced record 1996 earnings earlier Tuesday, took six new compounds into development last year.
He said this brought the total of new prodcuts in development to 18, excluding products awaiting marketing approval such as Seroquel for schizophrenia and Zomig for migraine.

Barnes said an anti-cancer drug, Faslodex, had been taken into late-stage studies for treatment of advanced breast cancer, and had started intermediate, or Phase II, trials for benign gynaecological disease.

Finance director John Mayo said Tomudex, a drug which has already been approved in 11 countries for treatment of colo-rectal cancer, "has shown equivalence on survival and efficacy to the current standard therapy," citing mature data from recent trials published in Italy on Monday.
"Good efficacy, together with health economic benefits and less side effects, should mean that Tomudex has an important role to play in the treatment of colo-rectal cancer," Mayo said.
Zeneca's managemtent said one of its aims was to become the world's number one cancer company through its pipeline of drugs and the Salick cancer care company based in the U.S.
Zeneca is currently number two in terms of cancer drug sales, behind Bristol Myers Squibb Co of the U.S.
